images.caption: Figure 1:Spatiotemporal evolution of DLA aggregates across four test configurations. Rows correspond to: (a–c) classic DLA with single central seed; (d–f) multiple seeds with 12 randomly distributed nucleation sites; (g–i) radial injection from fixed radiusRinj=180R_{\mathrm{inj}}=180; (j–l) high density withNw=25,000N_{w}=25{,}000walkers. Columns represent early (∼\sim10%), middle (∼\sim50%), and final (100%) growth stages. Particle countsNNand completion percentages are indicated in each panel. Color encodes radial distance from aggregate centroid (dark red: center; bright orange: tips). Lattice size512×512512\times 512for all cases.

Figure 2:Mass-radius scaling analysis for fractal dimension extraction. (a) Classic DLA:Df=1.711±0.080D_{f}=1.711\pm 0.080,R2=0.9875R^{2}=0.9875. (b) Radial injection:Df=1.713±0.077D_{f}=1.713\pm 0.077,R2=0.9854R^{2}=0.9854. (c) High density:Df=1.870±0.055D_{f}=1.870\pm 0.055,R2=0.9950R^{2}=0.9950. Circles denote simulation data; solid red lines show linear regression fits; shaded bands indicate 95% confidence intervals; dashed teal lines represent the theoretical predictionDf=1.71D_{f}=1.71. The multiple seeds case is excluded as mass-radius analysis requires a single connected aggregate. Data filtered toM​(R)>10M(R)>10andR<0.8​RmaxR<0.8R_{\mathrm{max}}to exclude boundary effects and small-number fluctuations.

Figure 3:Growth dynamics analysis for all four DLA configurations. (a) Cumulative particle countN​(t)N(t)versus snapshot index, showing characteristic decelerating growth as aggregates enlarge. (b) Instantaneous growth rated​N/d​t\mathrm{d}N/\mathrm{d}tversus particle countNN, demonstrating monotonic decrease due to diffusive screening. (c) Normalized growth curvesN​(t)/NmaxN(t)/N_{\mathrm{max}}versus normalized timet/Tt/T, enabling direct comparison of growth kinetics. (d) Growth efficiencyN/ReffN/R_{\mathrm{eff}}(normalized) versust/Tt/T, whereReff=N1/DfR_{\mathrm{eff}}=N^{1/D_{f}}estimates the effective aggregate radius. Legend applies to all panels.

Figure 4:Information-theoretic characterization of DLA aggregate structure. (a) Shannon entropyH​(ε)H(\varepsilon)versus box sizeε\varepsilonon semi-logarithmic axes, quantifying spatial information content at each scale. (b) LacunarityΛ​(ε)\Lambda(\varepsilon)versusε\varepsilonon log-log axes, measuring scale-dependent heterogeneity (“gappiness”). (c) Box-counting dimensionD0D_{0}extraction via linear regression oflog⁡N​(ε)\log N(\varepsilon)versuslog⁡ε\log\varepsilon; fitted values indicated for each case. (d) Information dimensionD1D_{1}extraction fromH​(ε)H(\varepsilon)versuslog2⁡(1/ε)\log_{2}(1/\varepsilon); note consistent use oflog2\log_{2}matching Shannon entropy definition. For monofractal structures,D0≈D1≈D2≈Df≈1.71D_{0}\approx D_{1}\approx D_{2}\approx D_{f}\approx 1.71.
